text: In addition to using the name America, we will also refer to the continent as Abya Yala, a term used by the indigenous peoples of the continent (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).

Prerequisites

The game on this page aims to reinforce knowledge of indigenous numerical systems and the numbers we use today. Before starting, we suggest studying the following previous pages:

• Our sides are equal: in this first text, we show for people their body symmetry.
  • Couting: we introduce the idea of counting using our body.
  • Beyond fingers: exploring the limitations and the necessity of new tools to count.

Training steps

Objective:There is a relationship between our fingers and the symbols we use to count. In this step as a trainee, your mission is to complete the counting sequence using different models. This training will help reinforce your knowledge.

Rules: Select a way to represent the counting. Half of the values will be preloaded, and you will complete the other half using the arrows on the side. When you finish, you can restart the training by clicking the "Start again" button.
Couting model:
Translate the second line using arrows on side.IncreaseDecrease

Discovering America (Abya Ayala)

Objective and rules:Our objective is to translate the indigenous numerations that will appear, either on Yupana format or in the Mesoamerican format. With each value you translate, you will learn about an indigenous region in America (Abya Ayala). You can advance to the next mission by clicking on . At the end, you will receive a medal () for your work.
Note: To read a number on the Yupana, we must look at all four squares. In contrast, Mesoamerican numbers are represented in a single square.
Translate the first line and discover indigenous constructions.

We work with Yupana using the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" method, developed and published by Dhavit Prem (Prem, Dhavit) of the Yupanki Association (Prem, Dhavit, ).
The use of Mesoamerican numbers is based on the work of Orlando Josué Casares Contreras, José M. Gamboa Cetina y Venus Sarahí Estrella Cabrera (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , (Revista)). Additionally, we incorporate the work of Francisco Barriga Puente, and Ximena Catepillán (Puente, Francisco Barriga, ; Catepillán, Ximena, ).
Finally, we utilize various counting methods inspired by the work of Francisco A. González Redondo et al. (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., ).
